awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will bring together an international community of experts from multiple disciplines to take action on the outcomes and recommendations from Tephra workshops in 2014 and 2017, and seed the implementation and use of cyber based tools and technologies in tephra studies. Tephra studies relate a unique volcanic product that helps researchers to understand volcanic behavior, past eruptions, and the effects of volcanoes on climate and the environment. They provide time markers for geologic and prehistoric human events. The workshop and follow on activities will be useful to provide information for paleoclimatologists, archeologists and others who study environmental change and its impacts on society, and will provide tools for consistent evaluation of tephra layers, which are used extensively to date climatological and environmental transitions. The Broader Impacts of these efforts include the increased information access to a broad scientific community, and collaboration and communication between diverse researchers. The 50 researchers will include participants from under-represented groups in the geosciences.

The researchers intend to hold a series of focused, international tephra workshops in 2019 to 2021.The goals are to produce: (1) publication of a consensus paper to draw attention to the demand, and to develop a coordination plan for creating comparable datasets across disciplines, (2) multiple open access products, for example, best practice templates, data collection and processing templates with end-user oriented minimum sets of required data, and (3) collation of databases and already built tools/code/software for data processing. These products are linked to future directions for the communities interested in tephra.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Tephra, or volcanic ash as it is often known, is widely used in a number of scientific disciplines, since it provides the only opportunity to determine exact time horizons -- even to the day -- that span the globe, even after millions of years of geologic time.  The major goals of the project were to convene a series of focused, international tephra workshops in 2019 - 2023 to allow researchers from the many interested disciplines to work towards a global tephra data system. However, we have been unable to take full advantage of the unmatched time information in tephra layers by an inability consistently to compare information on tephra layers from region to region, and through time, because of a lack of standardization.  Specifically, therefore, the goals were to produce, from the proposed workshops: (1) publication of a consensus paper to draw attention to the need for coordinated effort in tephra studies, and to develop a coordination plan for creating comparable tephra datasets across disciplines, (2) multiple open access products, for example, best practice templates, data collection and processing templates with "end user" oriented minimum sets of required data, and (3) collation of databases and already built tools/code/software for data processing. 

We began the process with a workshop in Dublin, Ireland, in summer, 2019, in association with the meeting of the International Quaternary Association.   About a dozen, select, generally senior researchers participated in the workshop from 27 August to 3 September.  Results were a set of four workbook style templates0 with protocols for tephra data collection, analysis and correlation. We continued to work with the community to refine and finalize each workbook. These are seen as evolving products, and the community was invited to continue to update these as situations change.  The latest version of the workbooks is always available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3866266.

The second (virtual) workshop was prepared for and held in Feb/March, 2022. Briefly, the main result of this multi-day workshop was a poll of the tephra community on directions and goals.  See website with outcomes at: mhttps://tephrochronology.org/cot/Tephra2022/, and YouTube channel with archived videos at: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbh6E2bBnxrzTibbJkUhYAQ.   We worked intensively with SESAR/EarthChem to complete and update a Tephra Community Portal in EarthChem. See the portal at: https://www.earthchem.org
/communities/tephra/.  We had started the consensus paper at the first workshop, but finished and published it in 2022. See: Wallace, K.L., Bursik, M.I., Kuehn, S., Kurbatov, A.V., Abbott, P., Bonadonna, C., Cashman, K., Davies, S.M., Jensen, B., Lane, C. and Plunkett, G., 2022. Community established best practice recommendations for tephra studies—from collection through analysis. Scientific Data, 9(1), pp.1-11, https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-022-01515-y.

We held two international workshops in the final year of the project. The workshop "From field apps to data repositories: Improving tephra data
discoverability, access, and workflows to support next generation research" was held 28-29 January, 2023, in association with the IAVCEI Scientific Assembly, 2023, Rotorua, New Zealand. In recent years, there had been increasing development of field apps, community best practices, international standards, data repositories, and other initiatives relating to scientific data across disciplines, and these advances were changing how many do science. In tephra studies, multiple data repositories had been developed, and best practices continued to be refined. The workshop therefore involved training and hands-on experience with software tools and databases. It made use of the Strabo field app and database (https://www.strabospot.org), the EarthChem Library (http://www.earthchem.org), the EarthChem Synthesis (PetDB), and the IGSN sample identifier (http://www.geosamples.org/getigsn).

Finally the "Tephra Data Systems 2023" Workshop was held June 7–11, 2023, at Playa at Summer Lake, Oregon, USA (https://playasummerlake.org/). The workshop was dedicated to the continued development of tephrochronology data systems to enable the global recognition of these time markers. Eighteen researchers from seven countries participated in field work, talks, brainstorming and contributing to a workshop white paper. The goals of the workshop were thus to:
* Describe a grand vision of a global tephra data system,
* Develop a model of the process of collection of data on tephra layers, entry of
those data into a database, and connecting those data among databases,
* Share software tools (e.g., scripts, source code) for manipulating data and
discussing the goal of data formats conducive to visualization tools, and
* Discuss long term archiving of data – how this can be accomplished to ease the burden on future researchers.

At the workshop, we worked closely with StraboSpot developers to improve the tephra data input product in StraboSpot, and began in-depth discussions with EarthChem and researchers around the globe to begin building a FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reuseable) data system framework.  Researchers presented numerous examples of FAIR data in tephra studies, and gained feedback on how to continue to move the tephra community forward in a FAIR world.  We produced a final publication to the community summarizing the best practices workbooks, and urging their use (Microscopy and Microanalysis, 29 (Suppl 1), 2023, 242, https://doi.org/10.1093/micmic/ozad067.108).
